unit: Unit 8 | Inference for Categorical Data: Chi-Square
title: Math Program: Expected Counts
question_text:
Suppose a high school principal wishes to determine if students in her after-school math program perform better than those not in the program.
The principal randomly selected $115\text{ students}$ for an after-school study session that runs $3\text{ days per week}$ for $1\text{ hour}$ each day, focusing solely on math.
The grade distribution of these students’ math grades is compared to the historical grade distribution of students’ math grades at this high school. The data is below:

After-School Program (Counts)28383694
Historical Grade Distribution (%)18%32%25%20%5%
solution:
The expected counts are counts one would expect to get if the null hypothesis were true.

If the null hypothesis were true, then $18\%$ of the sample would get As, $32\%$ would get Bs, and so on.

By that logic,

$(0.18) \times 115 = 20.7$ would get A's
$(0.32) \times 115 = 36.8$ would get B's
$(0.25) \times 115 = 28.75$ would get C's
$(0.2) \times 115 = 23$ would get D's
$(0.05) \times 115 = 5.75$ would get F's

This matches Choice 'E'.

Explanation of Distractors

Choice 'A' is incorrect; this gives observed counts.

Choices 'B' and 'C' are incorrect; these give percentages, not counts.

Choice 'D' is incorrect; this rounds the expected counts; NEVER round the expected counts, as these expected counts are used in calculating the chi-squared test statistic.
